workout_file.author: Zwift
workout_file.name: Week 1.3 - Wild Starts
workout_file.description: A Zwift race start simulation workout with an initial very hard effort followed by a sweet spot ramp.

textevent.message: Welcome to today's workout, my friend! Let's get started with a warmup.
As always, keep your cadence comfortable here and ease into the day.
Take a quick look to make sure you have your fluids, fan, and towel handy.
As you feel warmer, increase your cadence steadily to aid in warming your muscles up.
Halfway through today's warmup, here's what's in store today...
A very important part of Zwift racing is their start.
They can be compared to a cyclocross start, if you've ever done cross.
In a nutshell, people go wild off the start and sprint for the 1st 10-30sec.
So, it's your job today to practice these wild starts.
And ideally improve your tolerance to 'suffer' a bit at the start of a race.
More specifically, we'll tackle 3 intervals today.
Each start with a hard effort at 150% FTP, followed by a sweet spot ramp.
With 5min of recovery in between each one :-)
Let's continue on with the warmup.
1min to go for today's warmup, then we'll take it easy for a couple minutes.
Nicely done, let's take it nice and easy for a couple of minutes now.
Take a few deep breaths and sip some fluids here.
Our 1st interval is just ahead, we're start with 1min at 150% FTP.
Aim for 110+ RPM for these! LET's GO!
GO GO GO! Get off the line quickly now!
Don't let up here! Make the initial selection.
Just a little more to go before the group settles down!
Great effort! Let's settle into a hard effort now at a more comfortable cadence.
This is your chance to learn to recover under pressure.
Deep breaths now and stay in the group to capitalize on the draft.
You should feel somewhat recovered by now, but keep breathing and drinking.
Great effort so far! These intervals are perfect training for Zwift races.
This should start to feel like work again...Stay with it!
Final minute of this 1st interval, DIG!
Way to go! That's 1 down with 2 to go.
We're going to take a 5min recovery now.
Make sure to towel off, take a drink, and breathe here. We'll catch up with 1min to go.
All right, interval #2 is just ahead.
This time we're going to reduce the start effort to 45sec.
But, still at 150% FTP, with a 9min 15sec sweet spot ramp to follow.
Bring your cadence up to 110+ RPM now...
UP UP UP!
C'mon! WORK!
NICE! Now, settle into sweet spot quickly again and keep a steady cadence.
Breathe...Recover now - You're in control!
Great work! Learning to 'suffer' a little bit will improve your Zwift racing craft.
Make sure you're still drinking here.
It's easy to forget to drink while under pressure.
But, becoming dehydrated will decrease your performance substantially.
You're more than halfway done now, and looking GREAT!
Keep on steadily increasing your effort over these final minutes.
Imagine yourself in a race scenario for these intervals and staying in the wheels.
Visualization can be really motivating and allow you to dig even deeper.
Final minute of our 2nd interval! Stay strong all the way to the arch!
Great work so far today! We're going to take a nice recovery again here.
And we'll catch up again with 1min to go.
Ready to CRUSH this finale?
The start effort will be 30sec this time, with a 9min 30sec ramp to follow.
You got this, my friend!
Cadence up to 110+ RPM now.
LET'S GO! UP UP UP!
Nice! That may be the shortest hard start today.
But, the 3rd interval of the day will make it feel tough!
Being okay with pushing yourself under fatigue is another important aspect of Zwift racing.
Since most can get through the 1st or 2nd lap of a race in a group.
But the final lap is where you separate the wheat from the chaff!
Stay in control now, and grit your teeth to the finish line!
More than halfway through our final interval today! Way to go!
Take a couple sips of fluid here.
Final minute! Keep it up!
Push all the way to the arch!
All right! Way to crush it today!
That 'flavor' of workout is something you'll see frequently over this plan.
Since it mimics the specificity of Zwift racing very well.
We're going to take 5mins and cooldown here, then we check another one off in the books.
See you next time :-)
